**Computer data storage** , often called **storage** or **memory** , is a
technology consisting of [computer](/wiki/Computer "Computer") components and
[recording media](/wiki/Data_storage_device "Data storage device") that are
used to retain digital [data](/wiki/Data_\(computing\) "Data \(computing\)").
It is a core function and fundamental component of computers.[1]:15–16

The [central processing unit](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central
processing unit") (CPU) of a computer is what manipulates data by performing
computations. In practice, almost all computers use a [storage
hierarchy](/wiki/Memory_hierarchy "Memory hierarchy"),[1]:468–473 which puts
fast but expensive and small storage options close to the CPU and slower but
larger and cheaper options farther away. Generally the fast volatile
technologies (which lose data when off power) are referred to as "memory",
while slower persistent technologies are referred to as "storage".

In the [Von Neumann architecture](/wiki/Von_Neumann_architecture "Von Neumann
architecture"), the CPU consists of two main parts: The [control
unit](/wiki/Control_unit "Control unit") and the [arithmetic logic
unit](/wiki/Arithmetic_logic_unit "Arithmetic logic unit") (ALU). The former
controls the flow of data between the CPU and memory, while the latter
performs arithmetic and [logical operations](/wiki/Bitwise_operations "Bitwise
operations") on data.

##
Functionality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Functionality")]

Without a significant amount of memory, a computer would merely be able to
perform fixed operations and immediately output the result. It would have to
be reconfigured to change its behavior. This is acceptable for devices such as
desk [calculators](/wiki/Calculator "Calculator"), [digital signal
processors](/wiki/Digital_signal_processing "Digital signal processing"), and
other specialized devices. [Von Neumann](/wiki/Von_Neumann_architecture "Von
Neumann architecture") machines differ in having a memory in which they store
their operating [instructions](/wiki/Instruction_\(computer_science\)
"Instruction \(computer science\)") and data.[1]:20 Such computers are more
versatile in that they do not need to have their hardware reconfigured for
each new program, but can simply be [reprogrammed](/wiki/Computer_programming
"Computer programming") with new in-memory instructions; they also tend to be
simpler to design, in that a relatively simple processor may keep
[state](/wiki/Program_state "Program state") between successive computations
to build up complex procedural results. Most modern computers are von Neumann
machines.

## Data organization and
representation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Data organization and representation")]

A modern [digital computer](/wiki/Computer "Computer") represents
[data](/wiki/Data "Data") using the [binary numeral
system](/wiki/Binary_numeral_system "Binary numeral system"). Text, numbers,
pictures, audio, and nearly any other form of information can be converted
into a string of [bits](/wiki/Bit "Bit"), or binary digits, each of which has
a value of 1 or 0. The most common unit of storage is the [byte](/wiki/Byte
"Byte"), equal to 8 bits. A piece of information can be handled by any
computer or device whose storage space is large enough to accommodate _the
binary representation of the piece of information_ , or simply
[data](/wiki/Data_\(computing\) "Data \(computing\)"). For example, the
[complete works of Shakespeare](/wiki/Complete_works_of_Shakespeare "Complete
works of Shakespeare"), about 1250 pages in print, can be stored in about five
[megabytes](/wiki/Megabyte "Megabyte") (40 million bits) with one byte per
character.

Data are [encoded](/wiki/Encoding "Encoding") by assigning a bit pattern to
each [character](/wiki/Character_\(computing\) "Character \(computing\)"),
[digit](/wiki/Numerical_digit "Numerical digit"), or
[multimedia](/wiki/Multimedia "Multimedia") object. Many standards exist for
encoding (e.g., [character encodings](/wiki/Character_encoding "Character
encoding") like [ASCII](/wiki/ASCII "ASCII"), image encodings like
[JPEG](/wiki/JPEG "JPEG"), video encodings like [MPEG-4](/wiki/MPEG-4
"MPEG-4")).

By adding bits to each encoded unit, redundancy allows the computer to both
detect errors in coded data and correct them based on mathematical algorithms.
Errors generally occur in low probabilities due to [random](/wiki/Random
"Random") bit value flipping, or "physical bit fatigue", loss of the physical
bit in storage of its ability to maintain a distinguishable value (0 or 1), or
due to errors in inter or intra-computer communication. A random [bit
flip](/wiki/RAM_parity "RAM parity") (e.g., due to random
[radiation](/wiki/Radiation "Radiation")) is typically corrected upon
detection. A bit, or a group of malfunctioning physical bits (not always the
specific defective bit is known; group definition depends on specific storage
device) is typically automatically fenced-out, taken out of use by the device,
and replaced with another functioning equivalent group in the device, where
the corrected bit values are restored (if possible). The [cyclic redundancy
check](/wiki/Cyclic_redundancy_check "Cyclic redundancy check") (CRC) method
is typically used in communications and storage for [error
detection](/wiki/Error_detection_and_correction "Error detection and
correction"). A detected error is then retried.

[Data compression](/wiki/Data_compression "Data compression") methods allow in
many cases (such as a database) to represent a string of bits by a shorter bit
string ("compress") and reconstruct the original string ("decompress") when
needed. This utilizes substantially less storage (tens of percents) for many
types of data at the cost of more computation (compress and decompress when
needed). Analysis of trade-off between storage cost saving and costs of
related computations and possible delays in data availability is done before
deciding whether to keep certain data compressed or not.

For [security reasons](/wiki/Data_security "Data security") certain types of
data (e.g., credit-card information) may be kept [encrypted](/wiki/Encryption
"Encryption") in storage to prevent the possibility of unauthorized
information reconstruction from chunks of storage snapshots.

"Edit section: Hierarchy of storage")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Computer_storage_types.svg/350px-
Computer_storage_types.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Computer_storage_types.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Computer_storage_types.svg "Enlarge")

Various forms of storage, divided according to their distance from the
[central processing unit](/wiki/Central_processing_unit "Central processing
unit"). The fundamental components of a general-purpose computer are
[arithmetic and logic unit](/wiki/Arithmetic_logic_unit "Arithmetic logic
unit"), [control circuitry](/wiki/Control_unit "Control unit"), storage space,
and [input/output](/wiki/Input/output "Input/output") devices. Technology and
capacity as in common [home computers](/wiki/Home_computer "Home computer")
around 2005.

Generally, the lower a storage is in the hierarchy, the lesser its
[bandwidth](/wiki/Bandwidth_\(computing\) "Bandwidth \(computing\)") and the
greater its access [latency](/wiki/Latency_\(engineering\) "Latency
\(engineering\)") is from the CPU. This traditional division of storage to
primary, secondary, tertiary and off-line storage is also guided by cost per
bit.

In contemporary usage, "memory" is usually [semiconductor](/wiki/Semiconductor
"Semiconductor") storage read-write [random-access memory](/wiki/Random-
access_memory "Random-access memory"), typically [DRAM](/wiki/DRAM "DRAM")
(dynamic RAM) or other forms of fast but temporary storage. "Storage" consists
of storage devices and their media not directly accessible by the
[CPU](/wiki/CPU "CPU") ([secondary](/wiki/Secondary_storage "Secondary
storage") or [tertiary storage](/wiki/Tertiary_storage "Tertiary storage")),
typically [hard disk drives](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive"),
[optical disc](/wiki/Optical_disc "Optical disc") drives, and other devices
slower than RAM but [non-volatile](/wiki/Non-volatile_memory "Non-volatile
memory") (retaining contents when powered down).[2]

Historically, _memory_ has been called _core memory_ , _main memory_ , _real
storage_ or _internal memory_. Meanwhile, non-volatile storage devices have
been referred to as _secondary storage_ , _external memory_ or
_auxiliary/peripheral storage_.

### Primary
storage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Primary storage")]

Main article: [Computer memory](/wiki/Computer_memory "Computer memory")

_Primary storage_ (also known as _main memory_ or _internal memory_), often
referred to simply as _memory_ , is the only one directly accessible to the
CPU. The CPU continuously reads instructions stored there and executes them as
required. Any data actively operated on is also stored there in uniform
manner.

Historically, [early computers](/wiki/History_of_computing_hardware "History
of computing hardware") used [delay lines](/wiki/Delay_line_memory "Delay line
memory"), [Williams tubes](/wiki/Williams_tube "Williams tube"), or rotating
[magnetic drums](/wiki/Drum_memory "Drum memory") as primary storage. By 1954,
those unreliable methods were mostly replaced by [magnetic core
memory](/wiki/Magnetic_core_memory "Magnetic core memory"). Core memory
remained dominant until the 1970s, when advances in [integrated
circuit](/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated circuit") technology allowed
[semiconductor memory](/wiki/Semiconductor_memory "Semiconductor memory") to
become economically competitive.

This led to modern [random-access memory](/wiki/Random-access_memory "Random-
access memory") (RAM). It is small-sized, light, but quite expensive at the
same time. (The particular types of RAM used for primary storage are also
[volatile](/wiki/Volatile_memory "Volatile memory"), i.e. they lose the
information when not powered).

As shown in the diagram, traditionally there are two more sub-layers of the
primary storage, besides main large-capacity RAM:

  * [Processor registers](/wiki/Processor_register "Processor register") are located inside the processor. Each register typically holds a [word](/wiki/Word_\(computer_architecture\) "Word \(computer architecture\)") of data (often 32 or 64 bits). CPU instructions instruct the [arithmetic logic unit](/wiki/Arithmetic_logic_unit "Arithmetic logic unit") to perform various calculations or other operations on this data (or with the help of it). Registers are the fastest of all forms of computer data storage.
  * [Processor cache](/wiki/CPU_cache "CPU cache") is an intermediate stage between ultra-fast registers and much slower main memory. It was introduced solely to improve the performance of computers. Most actively used information in the main memory is just duplicated in the cache memory, which is faster, but of much lesser capacity. On the other hand, main memory is much slower, but has a much greater storage capacity than processor registers. Multi-level [hierarchical cache](/wiki/Memory_hierarchy "Memory hierarchy") setup is also commonly used— _primary cache_ being smallest, fastest and located inside the processor; _secondary cache_ being somewhat larger and slower.

Main memory is directly or indirectly connected to the central processing unit
via a _memory bus_. It is actually two buses (not on the diagram): an [address
bus](/wiki/Address_bus "Address bus") and a [data bus](/wiki/Bus_\(computing\)
"Bus \(computing\)"). The CPU firstly sends a number through an address bus, a
number called [memory address](/wiki/Memory_address "Memory address"), that
indicates the desired location of data. Then it reads or writes the data in
the [memory cells](/wiki/Memory_cell_\(computing\) "Memory cell
\(computing\)") using the data bus. Additionally, a [memory management
unit](/wiki/Memory_management_unit "Memory management unit") (MMU) is a small
device between CPU and RAM recalculating the actual memory address, for
example to provide an abstraction of [virtual memory](/wiki/Virtual_memory
"Virtual memory") or other tasks.

As the RAM types used for primary storage are volatile (uninitialized at start
up), a computer containing only such storage would not have a source to read
instructions from, in order to start the computer. Hence, [non-volatile
primary storage](/wiki/Non-volatile_memory "Non-volatile memory") containing a
small startup program ([BIOS](/wiki/BIOS "BIOS")) is used to
[bootstrap](/wiki/Bootstrapping_\(computing\) "Bootstrapping \(computing\)")
the computer, that is, to read a larger program from non-volatile _secondary_
storage to RAM and start to execute it. A non-volatile technology used for
this purpose is called ROM, for [read-only memory](/wiki/Read-only_memory
"Read-only memory") (the terminology may be somewhat confusing as most ROM
types are also capable of _[random access](/wiki/Random_access "Random
access")_).

Many types of "ROM" are not literally _read only_ , as updates to them are
possible; however it is slow and memory must be erased in large portions
before it can be re-written. Some [embedded systems](/wiki/Embedded_system
"Embedded system") run programs directly from ROM (or similar), because such
programs are rarely changed. Standard computers do not store non-rudimentary
programs in ROM, and rather, use large capacities of secondary storage, which
is non-volatile as well, and not as costly.

Recently, _primary storage_ and _secondary storage_ in some uses refer to what
was historically called, respectively, _secondary storage_ and _tertiary
storage_.[3]

### Secondary
storage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Secondary storage")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/35-Desktop-Hard-
Drive.jpg/220px-35-Desktop-Hard-Drive.jpg)](/wiki/File:35-Desktop-Hard-
Drive.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:35-Desktop-Hard-Drive.jpg "Enlarge")

A [hard disk drive](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive") with protective
cover removed

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Mergefrom.svg/50px-
Mergefrom.svg.png)| It has been suggested that _[Auxiliary
memory](/wiki/Auxiliary_memory "Auxiliary memory")_ be
[merged](/wiki/Wikipedia:Merging "Wikipedia:Merging") into this article.
([Discuss](/wiki/Talk:Auxiliary_memory#Merge_to_Secondary_Storage
"Talk:Auxiliary memory"))_Proposed since November 2017._  
---|---  
  
Main article: [Auxiliary memory](/wiki/Auxiliary_memory "Auxiliary memory")

_Secondary storage_ (also known as _external memory_ or _auxiliary storage_),
differs from primary storage in that it is not directly accessible by the CPU.
The computer usually uses its [input/output](/wiki/Input/output
"Input/output") channels to access secondary storage and transfers the desired
data using [intermediate area](/wiki/Data_buffer "Data buffer") in primary
storage. Secondary storage does not lose the data when the device is powered
down—it is non-volatile. Per unit, it is typically also two orders of
magnitude less expensive than primary storage. Modern computer systems
typically have two orders of magnitude more secondary storage than primary
storage and data are kept for a longer time there.

In modern computers, [hard disk drives](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk
drive") are usually used as secondary storage. The time taken to access a
given byte of information stored on a hard disk is typically a few thousandths
of a second, or milliseconds. By contrast, the time taken to access a given
byte of information stored in random-access memory is measured in billionths
of a second, or nanoseconds. This illustrates the significant access-time
difference which distinguishes solid-state memory from rotating magnetic
storage devices: hard disks are typically about a million times slower than
memory. Rotating [optical storage](/wiki/Optical_disc_drive "Optical disc
drive") devices, such as [CD](/wiki/Compact_Disc "Compact Disc") and
[DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") drives, have even longer access times. With disk
drives, once the disk read/write head reaches the proper placement and the
data of interest rotates under it, subsequent data on the track are very fast
to access. To reduce the seek time and rotational latency, data are
transferred to and from disks in large contiguous blocks.

When data reside on disk, accessing them in large blocks to hide latency
offers an opportunity to design efficient [external memory
algorithms](/wiki/External_memory_algorithms "External memory algorithms").
Sequential or block access on disks is orders of magnitude faster than random
access, and many sophisticated paradigms have been developed to design
efficient algorithms based upon sequential and block access. Another way to
reduce the I/O bottleneck is to use multiple disks in parallel in order to
increase the bandwidth between primary and secondary memory.[4]

Some other examples of secondary storage technologies are [flash
memory](/wiki/Flash_memory "Flash memory") (e.g. [USB flash
drives](/wiki/USB_flash_drive "USB flash drive") or keys), [floppy
disks](/wiki/Floppy_disk "Floppy disk"), [magnetic
tape](/wiki/Magnetic_tape_data_storage "Magnetic tape data storage"), [paper
tape](/wiki/Punched_tape "Punched tape"), [punched cards](/wiki/Punched_card
"Punched card"), standalone [RAM disks](/wiki/RAM_disk "RAM disk"), and
[Iomega Zip drives](/wiki/Iomega_Zip_drive "Iomega Zip drive").

The secondary storage is often formatted according to a [file
system](/wiki/File_system "File system") format, which provides the
abstraction necessary to organize data into [files](/wiki/Computer_file
"Computer file") and [directories](/wiki/Directory_\(computing\) "Directory
\(computing\)"), providing also additional information (called
[metadata](/wiki/Metadata "Metadata")) describing the owner of a certain file,
the access time, the access permissions, and other information.

Most computer [operating systems](/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system")
use the concept of [virtual memory](/wiki/Virtual_memory "Virtual memory"),
allowing utilization of more primary storage capacity than is physically
available in the system. As the primary memory fills up, the system moves the
least-used chunks (_[pages](/wiki/Page_\(computing\) "Page \(computing\)")_)
to secondary storage devices (to a [swap file](/wiki/Paging "Paging") or [page
file](/wiki/Paging "Paging")), retrieving them later when they are needed. As
more of these retrievals from slower secondary storage are necessary, the more
the overall system performance is degraded.

### Tertiary
storage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Tertiary storage")]

See also: [Nearline storage](/wiki/Nearline_storage "Nearline storage") and
[Cloud storage](/wiki/Cloud_storage "Cloud storage")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/StorageTek_Powderhorn_tape_library.jpg/220px-
StorageTek_Powderhorn_tape_library.jpg)](/wiki/File:StorageTek_Powderhorn_tape_library.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:StorageTek_Powderhorn_tape_library.jpg "Enlarge")

A large [tape library](/wiki/Tape_library "Tape library"), with tape
cartridges placed on shelves in the front, and a robotic arm moving in the
back. Visible height of the library is about 180 cm.

_Tertiary storage_ or _tertiary memory_[5] provides a third level of storage.
Typically, it involves a robotic mechanism which will _mount_ (insert) and
_dismount_ removable mass storage media into a storage device according to the
system's demands; such data are often copied to secondary storage before use.
It is primarily used for archiving rarely accessed information since it is
much slower than secondary storage (e.g. 5–60 seconds vs. 1–10 milliseconds).
This is primarily useful for extraordinarily large data stores, accessed
without human operators. Typical examples include [tape
libraries](/wiki/Tape_library "Tape library") and [optical
jukeboxes](/wiki/Optical_jukebox "Optical jukebox").

When a computer needs to read information from the tertiary storage, it will
first consult a catalog [database](/wiki/Database "Database") to determine
which tape or disc contains the information. Next, the computer will instruct
a [robotic arm](/wiki/Industrial_robot "Industrial robot") to fetch the medium
and place it in a drive. When the computer has finished reading the
information, the robotic arm will return the medium to its place in the
library.

Tertiary storage is also known as _[nearline storage](/wiki/Nearline_storage
"Nearline storage")_ because it is "near to online". The formal distinction
between online, nearline, and offline storage is:[6]

  * Online storage is immediately available for I/O.
  * Nearline storage is not immediately available, but can be made online quickly without human intervention.
  * Offline storage is not immediately available, and requires some human intervention to become online.

For example, always-on spinning hard disk drives are online storage, while
spinning drives that spin down automatically, such as in massive arrays of
idle disks ([MAID](/wiki/MAID "MAID")), are nearline storage. Removable media
such as tape cartridges that can be automatically loaded, as in [tape
libraries](/wiki/Tape_library "Tape library"), are nearline storage, while
tape cartridges that must be manually loaded are offline storage.

### Off-line
storage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Off-line storage")]

_Off-line storage_ is a computer data storage on a medium or a device that is
not under the control of a [processing unit](/wiki/Central_processing_unit
"Central processing unit").[7] The medium is recorded, usually in a secondary
or tertiary storage device, and then physically removed or disconnected. It
must be inserted or connected by a human operator before a computer can access
it again. Unlike tertiary storage, it cannot be accessed without human
interaction.

[Off-line](/wiki/Online_and_offline "Online and offline") storage is used to
[transfer information](/wiki/Data_transmission "Data transmission"), since the
detached medium can be easily physically transported. Additionally, in case a
disaster, for example a fire, destroys the original data, a medium in a remote
location will probably be unaffected, enabling [disaster
recovery](/wiki/Disaster_recovery "Disaster recovery"). Off-line storage
increases general [information security](/wiki/Information_security
"Information security"), since it is physically inaccessible from a computer,
and data confidentiality or integrity cannot be affected by computer-based
attack techniques. Also, if the information stored for archival purposes is
rarely accessed, off-line storage is less expensive than tertiary storage.

In modern personal computers, most secondary and tertiary storage media are
also used for off-line storage. Optical discs and flash memory devices are
most popular, and to much lesser extent removable hard disk drives. In
enterprise uses, magnetic tape is predominant. Older examples are floppy
disks, Zip disks, or punched cards.

## Characteristics of
storage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Characteristics of storage")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Samsung-1GB-
DDR2-Laptop-RAM.jpg/250px-Samsung-1GB-DDR2-Laptop-
RAM.jpg)](/wiki/File:Samsung-1GB-DDR2-Laptop-RAM.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Samsung-1GB-DDR2-Laptop-RAM.jpg "Enlarge")

A 1 GB module of [laptop](/wiki/SO-DIMM "SO-DIMM") [DDR2](/wiki/DDR2_SDRAM
"DDR2 SDRAM") [RAM](/wiki/Random-access_memory "Random-access memory").

Storage technologies at all levels of the storage hierarchy can be
differentiated by evaluating certain core characteristics as well as measuring
characteristics specific to a particular implementation. These core
characteristics are volatility, mutability, accessibility, and addressability.
For any particular implementation of any storage technology, the
characteristics worth measuring are capacity and performance.

###
Volatility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Volatility")]

[Non-volatile memory](/wiki/Non-volatile_memory "Non-volatile memory") retains
the stored information even if not constantly supplied with electric power.[8]
It is suitable for long-term storage of information. [Volatile
memory](/wiki/Volatile_memory "Volatile memory") requires constant power to
maintain the stored information. The fastest memory technologies are volatile
ones, although that is not a universal rule. Since the primary storage is
required to be very fast, it predominantly uses volatile memory.

[Dynamic random-access memory](/wiki/Dynamic_random-access_memory "Dynamic
random-access memory") is a form of volatile memory that also requires the
stored information to be periodically reread and rewritten, or
[refreshed](/wiki/Memory_refresh "Memory refresh"), otherwise it would vanish.
[Static random-access memory](/wiki/Static_random-access_memory "Static
random-access memory") is a form of volatile memory similar to DRAM with the
exception that it never needs to be refreshed as long as power is applied; it
loses its content when the power supply is lost.

An [uninterruptible power supply](/wiki/Uninterruptible_power_supply
"Uninterruptible power supply") (UPS) can be used to give a computer a brief
window of time to move information from primary volatile storage into non-
volatile storage before the batteries are exhausted. Some systems, for example
[EMC Symmetrix](/wiki/EMC_Symmetrix "EMC Symmetrix"), have integrated
batteries that maintain volatile storage for several minutes.

###
Mutability[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Mutability")]

Read/write storage or mutable storage

    Allows information to be overwritten at any time. A computer without some amount of read/write storage for primary storage purposes would be useless for many tasks. Modern computers typically use read/write storage also for secondary storage.
Read only storage

    Retains the information stored at the time of manufacture, and _write once storage_ ([write once read many](/wiki/Write_once_read_many "Write once read many")) allows the information to be written only once at some point after manufacture. These are called _immutable storage_. Immutable storage is used for tertiary and off-line storage. Examples include [CD-ROM](/wiki/CD-ROM "CD-ROM") and [CD-R](/wiki/CD-R "CD-R").
Slow write, fast read storage

    Read/write storage which allows information to be overwritten multiple times, but with the write operation being much slower than the read operation. Examples include [CD-RW](/wiki/CD-RW "CD-RW") and [swayne memory](/w/index.php?title=Swayne_memory&action=edit&redlink=1 "Swayne memory \(page does not exist\)")

###
Accessibility[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Accessibility")]

[Random access](/wiki/Random_access "Random access")

    Any location in storage can be accessed at any moment in approximately the same amount of time. Such characteristic is well suited for primary and secondary storage. Most semiconductor memories and disk drives provide random access.
[Sequential access](/wiki/Sequential_access "Sequential access")

    The accessing of pieces of information will be in a serial order, one after the other; therefore the time to access a particular piece of information depends upon which piece of information was last accessed. Such characteristic is typical of off-line storage.

###
Addressability[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Addressability")]

Location-addressable

    Each individually accessible unit of information in storage is selected with its numerical [memory address](/wiki/Memory_address "Memory address"). In modern computers, location-addressable storage usually limits to primary storage, accessed internally by computer programs, since location-addressability is very efficient, but burdensome for humans.
[File addressable](/wiki/File_system "File system")

    Information is divided into _[files](/wiki/Computer_file "Computer file")_ of variable length, and a particular file is selected with [human-readable](/wiki/Human-readable "Human-readable") directory and file names. The underlying device is still location-addressable, but the [operating system](/wiki/Operating_system "Operating system") of a computer provides the file system [abstraction](/wiki/Abstraction_\(computer_science\) "Abstraction \(computer science\)") to make the operation more understandable. In modern computers, secondary, tertiary and off-line storage use file systems.
[Content-addressable](/wiki/Content-addressable_memory "Content-addressable
memory")

    Each individually accessible unit of information is selected based on the basis of (part of) the contents stored there. Content-addressable storage can be implemented using [software](/wiki/Software "Software") (computer program) or [hardware](/wiki/Personal_computer_hardware "Personal computer hardware") (computer device), with hardware being faster but more expensive option. Hardware content addressable memory is often used in a computer's [CPU cache](/wiki/CPU_cache "CPU cache").

###
Capacity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Capacity")]

Raw capacity

    The total amount of stored information that a storage device or medium can hold. It is expressed as a quantity of [bits](/wiki/Bit "Bit") or [bytes](/wiki/Byte "Byte") (e.g. 10.4 [megabytes](/wiki/Megabyte "Megabyte")).
[Memory storage density](/wiki/Memory_storage_density "Memory storage
density")

    The compactness of stored information. It is the storage capacity of a medium divided with a unit of length, area or volume (e.g. 1.2 megabytes per square inch).

###
Performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Performance")]

[Latency](/wiki/Latency_\(engineering\) "Latency \(engineering\)")

    The time it takes to access a particular location in storage. The relevant [unit of measurement](/wiki/Units_of_measurement "Units of measurement") is typically [nanosecond](/wiki/1_E-9_s "1 E-9 s") for primary storage, [millisecond](/wiki/Millisecond "Millisecond") for secondary storage, and [second](/wiki/Second "Second") for tertiary storage. It may make sense to separate read latency and write latency (especially for non-volatile memory[8]) and in case of sequential access storage, minimum, maximum and average latency.
[Throughput](/wiki/Throughput "Throughput")

    The rate at which information can be read from or written to the storage. In computer data storage, throughput is usually expressed in terms of megabytes per second (MB/s), though [bit rate](/wiki/Bit_rate "Bit rate") may also be used. As with latency, read rate and write rate may need to be differentiated. Also accessing media sequentially, as opposed to randomly, typically yields maximum throughput.
Granularity

    The size of the largest "chunk" of data that can be efficiently accessed as a single unit, e.g. without introducing additional latency.
Reliability

    The probability of spontaneous bit value change under various conditions, or overall [failure rate](/wiki/Failure_rate "Failure rate").

Utilities such as [hdparm](/wiki/Hdparm "Hdparm") and [sar](/wiki/Sar_\(Unix\)
"Sar \(Unix\)") can be used to measure IO performance in Linux.

### Energy
use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Energy use")]

  * Storage devices that reduce fan usage, automatically shut-down during inactivity, and low power hard drives can reduce energy consumption by 90 percent.[9]
  * 2.5-inch hard disk drives often consume less power than larger ones.[10][11] Low capacity [solid-state drives](/wiki/Solid-state_drive "Solid-state drive") have no moving parts and consume less power than hard disks.[12][13][14] Also, memory may use more power than hard disks.[14] Large caches, which are used to avoid hitting [memory wall](/wiki/Random-access_memory#Memory_wall "Random-access memory"), may also consume a large amount of power.[15]

## Storage
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Storage media")]

As of
2011[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit),
the most commonly used data storage media are semiconductor, magnetic, and
optical, while paper still sees some limited usage. Some other fundamental
storage technologies, such as all-flash arrays (AFAs) are proposed for
development.

###
Semiconductor[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Semiconductor")]

[Semiconductor memory](/wiki/Semiconductor_memory "Semiconductor memory") uses
[semiconductor](/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor")-based [integrated
circuits](/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated circuit") to store information.
A semiconductor memory chip may contain millions of tiny
[transistors](/wiki/Transistor "Transistor") or [capacitors](/wiki/Capacitor
"Capacitor"). Both _volatile_ and _non-volatile_ forms of semiconductor memory
exist. In modern computers, primary storage almost exclusively consists of
dynamic volatile semiconductor memory or [dynamic random-access
memory](/wiki/Dynamic_random-access_memory "Dynamic random-access memory").
Since the turn of the century, a type of non-volatile semiconductor memory
known as [flash memory](/wiki/Flash_memory "Flash memory") has steadily gained
share as off-line storage for home computers. Non-volatile semiconductor
memory is also used for secondary storage in various advanced electronic
devices and specialized computers that are designed for them.

As early as 2006, [notebook](/wiki/Laptop "Laptop") and [desktop
computer](/wiki/Desktop_computer "Desktop computer") manufacturers started
using flash-based [solid-state drives](/wiki/Solid-state_drive "Solid-state
drive") (SSDs) as default configuration options for the secondary storage
either in addition to or instead of the more traditional
HDD.[16][17][18][19][20]

[Magnetic storage](/wiki/Magnetic_storage "Magnetic storage") uses different
patterns of [magnetization](/wiki/Magnetization "Magnetization") on a
[magnetically](/wiki/Magnetism "Magnetism") coated surface to store
information. Magnetic storage is _non-volatile_. The information is accessed
using one or more read/write heads which may contain one or more recording
transducers. A read/write head only covers a part of the surface so that the
head or medium or both must be moved relative to another in order to access
data. In modern computers, magnetic storage will take these forms:

  * [Magnetic disk](/wiki/Disk_storage "Disk storage")
    * [Floppy disk](/wiki/Floppy_disk "Floppy disk"), used for off-line storage
    * [Hard disk drive](/wiki/Hard_disk_drive "Hard disk drive"), used for secondary storage
  * [Magnetic tape](/wiki/Magnetic_tape_data_storage "Magnetic tape data storage"), used for tertiary and off-line storage
  * [Carousel memory](/wiki/Carousel_memory "Carousel memory") (magnetic rolls)

In early computers, magnetic storage was also used as:

  * Primary storage in a form of [magnetic memory](/wiki/Drum_memory "Drum memory"), or [core memory](/wiki/Magnetic_core_memory "Magnetic core memory"), [core rope memory](/wiki/Core_rope_memory "Core rope memory"), [thin-film memory](/wiki/Thin-film_memory "Thin-film memory") and/or [twistor memory](/wiki/Twistor_memory "Twistor memory").
  * Tertiary (e.g. [NCR CRAM](/wiki/NCR_CRAM "NCR CRAM")) or off line storage in the form of magnetic cards.
  * Magnetic tape was then often used for secondary storage.

[Optical storage](/wiki/Optical_storage "Optical storage"), the typical
[optical disc](/wiki/Optical_disc "Optical disc"), stores information in
deformities on the surface of a circular disc and reads this information by
illuminating the surface with a [laser diode](/wiki/Laser_diode "Laser diode")
and observing the reflection. Optical disc storage is _non-volatile_. The
deformities may be permanent (read only media), formed once (write once media)
or reversible (recordable or read/write media). The following forms are
currently in common use:[21]

  * [CD](/wiki/Compact_Disc "Compact Disc"), [CD-ROM](/wiki/CD-ROM "CD-ROM"), [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD"), [BD-ROM](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc"): Read only storage, used for mass distribution of digital information (music, video, computer programs)
  * [CD-R](/wiki/CD-R "CD-R"), [DVD-R](/wiki/DVD-R "DVD-R"), [DVD+R](/wiki/DVD%2BR "DVD+R"), [BD-R](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc_recordable "Blu-ray Disc recordable"): Write once storage, used for tertiary and off-line storage
  * [CD-RW](/wiki/CD-RW "CD-RW"), [DVD-RW](/wiki/DVD-RW "DVD-RW"), [DVD+RW](/wiki/DVD%2BRW "DVD+RW"), [DVD-RAM](/wiki/DVD-RAM "DVD-RAM"), [BD-RE](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc_recordable "Blu-ray Disc recordable"): Slow write, fast read storage, used for tertiary and off-line storage
  * [Ultra Density Optical](/wiki/Ultra_Density_Optical "Ultra Density Optical") or UDO is similar in capacity to [BD-R or BD-RE](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc_recordable "Blu-ray Disc recordable") and is slow write, fast read storage used for tertiary and off-line storage.

[Magneto-optical disc storage](/wiki/Magneto-optical_drive "Magneto-optical
drive") is optical disc storage where the magnetic state on a
[ferromagnetic](/wiki/Ferromagnetism "Ferromagnetism") surface stores
information. The information is read optically and written by combining
magnetic and optical methods. Magneto-optical disc storage is _non-volatile_ ,
_sequential access_ , slow write, fast read storage used for tertiary and off-
line storage.

[3D optical data storage](/wiki/3D_optical_data_storage "3D optical data
storage") has also been proposed.

Light induced magnetization melting in magnetic photoconductors has also been
proposed for high-speed low-energy consumption magneto-optical storage.[22]

[Paper data storage](/wiki/Paper_data_storage "Paper data storage"), typically
in the form of [paper tape](/wiki/Punched_tape "Punched tape") or [punched
cards](/wiki/Punched_card "Punched card"), has long been used to store
information for automatic processing, particularly before general-purpose
computers existed. Information was recorded by punching holes into the paper
or cardboard medium and was read mechanically (or later optically) to
determine whether a particular location on the medium was solid or contained a
hole. A few technologies allow people to make marks on paper that are easily
read by machine—these are widely used for tabulating votes and grading
standardized tests. [Barcodes](/wiki/Barcode "Barcode") made it possible for
any object that was to be sold or transported to have some computer readable
information securely attached to it.

### Other storage media or
substrates[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Other storage media or substrates")]

Vacuum tube memory

    A [Williams tube](/wiki/Williams_tube "Williams tube") used a [cathode ray tube](/wiki/Cathode_ray_tube "Cathode ray tube"), and a [Selectron tube](/wiki/Selectron_tube "Selectron tube") used a large [vacuum tube](/wiki/Vacuum_tube "Vacuum tube") to store information. These primary storage devices were short-lived in the market, since Williams tube was unreliable and the Selectron tube was expensive.

Electro-acoustic memory

    [Delay line memory](/wiki/Delay_line_memory "Delay line memory") used [sound waves](/wiki/Longitudinal_wave "Longitudinal wave") in a substance such as [mercury](/wiki/Mercury_\(element\) "Mercury \(element\)") to store information. Delay line memory was dynamic volatile, cycle sequential read/write storage, and was used for primary storage.

[Optical tape](/wiki/Optical_tape "Optical tape")

    is a medium for optical storage generally consisting of a long and narrow strip of plastic onto which patterns can be written and from which the patterns can be read back. It shares some technologies with cinema film stock and optical discs, but is compatible with neither. The motivation behind developing this technology was the possibility of far greater storage capacities than either magnetic tape or optical discs.

[Phase-change memory](/wiki/Phase-change_memory "Phase-change memory")

    uses different mechanical phases of [phase-change material](/wiki/Phase-change_material "Phase-change material") to store information in an X-Y addressable matrix, and reads the information by observing the varying [electrical resistance](/wiki/Electrical_resistance "Electrical resistance") of the material. Phase-change memory would be non-volatile, random-access read/write storage, and might be used for primary, secondary and off-line storage. Most rewritable and many write once optical disks already use phase change material to store information.

[Holographic data storage](/wiki/Holographic_data_storage "Holographic data
storage")

    stores information optically inside [crystals](/wiki/Crystal "Crystal") or [photopolymers](/wiki/Photopolymer "Photopolymer"). Holographic storage can utilize the whole volume of the storage medium, unlike optical disc storage which is limited to a small number of surface layers. Holographic storage would be non-volatile, sequential access, and either write once or read/write storage. It might be used for secondary and off-line storage. See [Holographic Versatile Disc](/wiki/Holographic_Versatile_Disc "Holographic Versatile Disc") (HVD).

[Molecular memory](/wiki/Molecular_memory "Molecular memory")

    stores information in [polymer](/wiki/Polymer "Polymer") that can store electric charge. Molecular memory might be especially suited for primary storage. The theoretical storage capacity of molecular memory is 10 terabits per square inch.[23]

[Magnetic
photoconductors](/w/index.php?title=Magnetic_photoconductor&action=edit&redlink=1
"Magnetic photoconductor \(page does not exist\)")

    store magnetic information which can be modified by low-light illumination.[22]

[DNA](/wiki/DNA_digital_data_storage "DNA digital data storage")

    stores information in DNA [nucleotides](/wiki/Nucleotide "Nucleotide"). It was first done in 2012 when researchers achieved a rate of 1.28 petabytes per gram of DNA. In March 2017 scientists reported that a new algorithm called a DNA fountain achieved 85% of the theoretical limit, at 215 petabytes per gram of DNA.[24][25][26][27]

## Related
technologies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Related technologies")]

###
Redundancy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Redundancy")]

Main articles: [Disk mirroring](/wiki/Disk_mirroring "Disk mirroring") and
[RAID](/wiki/RAID "RAID")

See also: [Storage replication](/wiki/Storage_replication "Storage
replication")

While a group of bits malfunction may be resolved by error detection and
correction mechanisms (see above), storage device malfunction requires
different solutions. The following solutions are commonly used and valid for
most storage devices:

  * **Device[mirroring](/wiki/Disk_mirroring "Disk mirroring") (replication)** – A common solution to the problem is constantly maintaining an identical copy of device content on another device (typically of a same type). The downside is that this doubles the storage, and both devices (copies) need to be updated simultaneously with some overhead and possibly some delays. The upside is possible concurrent read of a same data group by two independent processes, which increases performance. When one of the replicated devices is detected to be defective, the other copy is still operational, and is being utilized to generate a new copy on another device (usually available operational in a pool of stand-by devices for this purpose).
  * **Redundant array of independent disks** (**[RAID](/wiki/RAID "RAID")**) – This method generalizes the device mirroring above by allowing one device in a group of N devices to fail and be replaced with the content restored (Device mirroring is RAID with N=2). RAID groups of N=5 or N=6 are common. N>2 saves storage, when comparing with N=2, at the cost of more processing during both regular operation (with often reduced performance) and defective device replacement.

Device mirroring and typical RAID are designed to handle a single device
failure in the RAID group of devices. However, if a second failure occurs
before the RAID group is completely repaired from the first failure, then data
can be lost. The probability of a single failure is typically small. Thus the
probability of two failures in a same RAID group in time proximity is much
smaller (approximately the probability squared, i.e., multiplied by itself).
If a database cannot tolerate even such smaller probability of data loss, then
the RAID group itself is replicated (mirrored). In many cases such mirroring
is done geographically remotely, in a different storage array, to handle also
recovery from disasters (see disaster recovery above).

### Network
connectivity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Network connectivity")]

A secondary or tertiary storage may connect to a computer utilizing [computer
networks](/wiki/Computer_network "Computer network"). This concept does not
pertain to the primary storage, which is shared between multiple processors to
a lesser degree.

  * [Direct-attached storage](/wiki/Direct-attached_storage "Direct-attached storage") (DAS) is a traditional mass storage, that does not use any network. This is still a most popular approach. This [retronym](/wiki/Retronym "Retronym") was coined recently, together with NAS and SAN.
  * [Network-attached storage](/wiki/Network-attached_storage "Network-attached storage") (NAS) is mass storage attached to a computer which another computer can access at file level over a [local area network](/wiki/Local_area_network "Local area network"), a private [wide area network](/wiki/Wide_area_network "Wide area network"), or in the case of [online file storage](/wiki/File_hosting_service "File hosting service"), over the [Internet](/wiki/Internet "Internet"). NAS is commonly associated with the [NFS](/wiki/Network_File_System_\(protocol\) "Network File System \(protocol\)") and [CIFS/SMB](/wiki/Server_Message_Block "Server Message Block") protocols.
  * [Storage area network](/wiki/Storage_area_network "Storage area network") (SAN) is a specialized network, that provides other computers with storage capacity. The crucial difference between NAS and SAN, is that NAS presents and manages file systems to client computers, while SAN provides access at block-addressing (raw) level, leaving it to attaching systems to manage data or file systems within the provided capacity. SAN is commonly associated with [Fibre Channel](/wiki/Fibre_Channel "Fibre Channel") networks.

### Robotic
storage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Computer_data_storage&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Robotic storage")]

Large quantities of individual magnetic tapes, and optical or magneto-optical
discs may be stored in robotic tertiary storage devices. In tape storage field
they are known as [tape libraries](/wiki/Tape_library "Tape library"), and in
optical storage field [optical jukeboxes](/wiki/Optical_jukebox "Optical
jukebox"), or optical disk libraries per analogy. Smallest forms of either
technology containing just one drive device are referred to as
[autoloaders](/wiki/Autoloader_\(data_storage_device\) "Autoloader \(data
storage device\)") or [autochangers](/wiki/Autochanger "Autochanger").

Robotic-access storage devices may have a number of slots, each holding
individual media, and usually one or more picking robots that traverse the
slots and load media to built-in drives. The arrangement of the slots and
picking devices affects performance. Important characteristics of such storage
are possible expansion options: adding slots, modules, drives, robots. Tape
libraries may have from 10 to more than 100,000 slots, and provide
[terabytes](/wiki/Terabyte "Terabyte") or [petabytes](/wiki/Petabyte
"Petabyte") of near-line information. Optical jukeboxes are somewhat smaller
solutions, up to 1,000 slots.

Robotic storage is used for [backups](/wiki/Backup "Backup"), and for high-
capacity archives in imaging, medical, and video industries. [Hierarchical
storage management](/wiki/Hierarchical_storage_management "Hierarchical
storage management") is a most known archiving strategy of automatically
_migrating_ long-unused files from fast hard disk storage to libraries or
jukeboxes. If the files are needed, they are _retrieved_ back to disk.
